## getIcon() function

Returns the icon glyph and color based on filename, extension, and indicator.

The lookup order is: 1. For directories: check IconDir, then default to hiddendir or dir 2. For files: - Check IconFileName for exact filename matches - Check for special cases (e.g., Go test files) - Check IconSubExt for compound extensions (e.g., .test.ts) - Check IconExt for file extensions - Default to hiddenfile or file based on hidden status 3. For executables: apply green color

**Signature:**

```typescript
declare function getIcon(name: string, ext: string, indicator: string): IconResult;
```

## Parameters

<table><thead><tr><th>

Parameter


</th><th>

Type


</th><th>

Description


</th></tr></thead>
<tbody><tr><td>

name


</td><td>

string


</td><td>

Base filename without extension


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

ext


</td><td>

string


</td><td>

File extension including the dot (e.g., ".ts")


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

indicator


</td><td>

string


</td><td>

File indicator from getIndicator()


</td></tr>
</tbody></table>

**Returns:**

[IconResult](./icons.iconresult.md)

Object with glyph (unicode character) and color (ANSI escape code)

## Example


```typescript
const { glyph, color } = getIcon('example', '.ts', '');
console.log(`${color}${glyph}\x1b[0m example.ts`);
```
